analyzed: dvitīyaḥ guṇaḥ

analyzed: śukla ādinā hi labdha sattākam vastu viśiṣyate

analyzed: sādhyaḥ pūrva aparībhūta avayavaḥ kriyā rūpaḥ
translated: The object to be accomplished is of the form of an action with parts that occur in sequence.

original: ḍitthādiśabdānāmantyabuddhinirgrāhyaṃ saṃhṛtakramaṃ svarūpaṃ vaktrā tadṛcchayā ḍitthādiṣvartheṣūpādhitvena saṃniveśyata iti so 'yaṃ saṃjñārūpo
analyzed: ḍittha ādi śabdānām antya buddhi nirgrāhyam saṃhṛta kramam sva rūpam vaktrā tadṛcchayā ḍittha ādiṣu artheṣu upādhi tvena saṃniveśyate iti saḥ yam
translated: The form of the last cognition grasped by the words dittha etc., which is contracted in sequence, is placed by the speaker as a limiting adjunct in the objects dittha etc. at his will. This is the nominal form

analyzed: yadṛcchā ātmakaḥ iti
translated: which is accidental.

original: gauḥśuklaścalo ḍittha ityādau catuṣṭayī śabdānāṃ pravṛttiḥ iti mahābhāṣyakāraḥ /

translated: The author of the Mahābhāṣya says that in a white cow, a moving cow, dittha, etc., there are four ways in which words are used.

analyzed: paramāṇu ādīnām tu guṇa madhya pāṭhāt pāribhāṣikam guṇa tvam

analyzed: yathā ekasya mukhasya khaḍga mukura taila ādi ālambana bhedāt
translated: Just as in the case of a single face, due to the difference of the supports such as a sword, a mirror, oil etc.,

original: himapayaḥśaṅkhādyāśrayeṣu paramārthato bhinneṣu śuklādiṣu yadvaśena śuklaḥ śukla ityādyabhinnābhidhānapratyayotpattistat śuklatvādi sāmānyam
analyzed: hima payaḥ śaṅkha ādi āśrayeṣu paramārthataḥ bhinneṣu śukla ādiṣu yad vaśena śuklaḥ śuklaḥ ityādi abhinna abhidhāna pratyaya utpattiḥ tat śukla tva ādi sāmānyam
translated: In the really different things such as snow, water, a conch etc. which are the substrata of white etc., that by the power of which the cognition and the expression of the non-different such as white, white etc. arise, that is the universal whiteness etc.

analyzed: guḍa taṇḍula ādi pāka ādiṣu evam eva pāka tva ādi
translated: In the cooking of jaggery, rice, etc., it is the same with cooking, etc.

original: bālavṛddhaśukādyudīriteṣu ḍitthādiśabdeṣu ca pratikṣaṇaṃ bhidyamāneṣu ḍitthādya'rtheṣu vā ḍitthatvādyastīti sarveṣāṃ śabdānāṃ jātireva pravṛttinimittamityanye
analyzed: bāla vṛddha śuka ādi udīriteṣu ḍittha ādi śabdeṣu ca pratikṣaṇam bhidyamāneṣu ḍittha ādi artheṣu vā ḍittha tva ādi asti iti sarveṣām śabdānām jātiḥ eva pravṛtti nimittam iti anye
translated: Others say that in the case of words like dittha uttered by children, the aged, parrots, etc., which are different every moment, or in the case of meanings like dittha, there is ditthatva, etc., so the universal alone is the cause of application of all words.

original: tadvān apoho vā śabdārthaḥ kaiściduktaṃ iti granthagauravabhayāt prakṛtānupayogācca na darśitam ////🔽sa mukhyo 'rthastatra mukhyo vyāpāro 'syābhidhocyate // MKpr //
analyzed: tadvān apohaḥ vā śabda arthaḥ kaiścid uktam iti grantha gaurava bhayāt prakṛta anupayogāt ca na darśitam  sa mukhyaḥ rthaḥ tatra mukhyaḥ syā abhidhā ucyate
translated: That which possesses it, or the exclusion, is said by some to be the meaning of a word. Fearing the bulkiness of the text and its irrelevance to the present topic, it has not been shown.🔽That primary meaning is the primary operation of this, called denotation.

analyzed: saḥ iti sākṣāt saṃketitaḥ
translated: That means what is directly signified.

analyzed: asya iti śabdasya
translated: Of this means of the word.

analyzed: mukhya artha bādhe tad yoge rūḍhitaḥ tha prayojanāt
translated: When there is obstruction of the primary meaning, due to its connection, from usage or from purpose,

original: anyo 'rtho lakṣyate yatsā lakṣaṇāropitā kriyā // MKpr //
analyzed: anyaḥ rthaḥ lakṣyate yat sā lakṣaṇa āropitā kriyā
translated: when another meaning is indicated, that is figurative indication.

original: karmani kuśalaḥ ityādau darbhagrahaṇādyayogāt gaṅgaāyāṃ ghoṣaḥ ityādau ca gaṅgādīnāṃ
analyzed: karmani kuśalaḥ ityādau darbha grahaṇa ādya yogāt ghoṣaḥ ityādau ca gaṅgā ādīnām
translated: In skilled in action, etc., the holding of darbha grass is not appropriate, and in the village on the Ganges, etc., the Ganges, etc.

original: ghoṣādyādhāratvāsaṃbhavāt mukhyārthasya bādhe vivecakatvādau sāmīpye ca saṃbandhe rūḍhitaḥ prasiddheḥ
analyzed: ghoṣa ādi ādhāra tva asaṃbhavāt mukhya arthasya bādhe vivecaka tva ādau sāmīpye ca saṃbandhe rūḍhitaḥ prasiddheḥ
translated: are not capable of being the substratum of the village, etc., when the primary meaning is obstructed, the relation of association is established by usage,

original: tathā gaṅgātaṭe ghoṣa ityādaiḥ prayogāt yeṣāṃ na tathā pratipattiḥ teṣāṃ pāvanatvādīnāṃ
analyzed: tathā gaṅgā taṭe ghoṣaḥ ityādaiḥ prayogāt yeṣām na tathā pratipattiḥ teṣām pāvana tva ādīnām
translated: Similarly, from usages like the village on the bank of the Ganges, for those who do not understand in that way, the purified nature etc.

original: dharmāṇāṃ tathāpratipādanātmanaḥ prayojanācca mukhyena amukhyo 'rtho lakṣyate yat
analyzed: dharmāṇām tathā pratipādana ātmanaḥ prayojanāt ca mukhyena amukhyaḥ rthaḥ lakṣyate yat
translated: of the properties are indicated in that way. And from the purpose of that, the primary meaning is indicated by the secondary meaning.

analyzed: saḥ āropitaḥ śabda vyāpāraḥ sāntara artha niṣṭhaḥ
translated: That superimposed operation of the word, which is based on a different meaning,

analyzed: lakṣaṇā
translated: is figurative usage.

analyzed: sva asiddhaye parākṣepaḥ para artham sva samarpaṇam
translated: The transference of one's own for one's own accomplishment, the offering of oneself for the sake of another,

original: upādānaṃ lakṣaṇaṃ cetyuktā śuddhaiva sā dvidhā // MKpr //
analyzed: upādānam lakṣaṇam ca iti uktā śuddhā eva sā dvidhā
translated: are said to be the two types of pure figurative usage.

original: kuntāḥ praviśanti yaṣṭayaḥ praviśanti ityādau kuntādibhirātmanaḥ praveśasiddhyarthaṃ svasaṃyoginaḥ puruṣā ākṣipyante /
analyzed: kuntāḥ praviśanti yaṣṭayaḥ praviśanti ityādau kunta ādibhiḥ ātmanaḥ praveśa siddhi artham sva saṃyoginaḥ puruṣāḥ ākṣipyante
translated: In expressions like the spear enters, the stick enters, etc., the men connected with the spear etc. are transferred for the purpose of accomplishing one's own entry by means of the spear etc.

analyzed: tatas yam lakṣaṇā
translated: Therefore, this is figurative usage by transference.

original: gauranubandhyaḥ ityādau śruticoditamanubandhanaṃ kathaṃ me syāditi jātyā vyaktirākṣipyate na tu śabdenocyate
analyzed: gauḥ anubandhyaḥ ityādau śruti coditam anubandhanam katham me syāt iti jātyā vyaktiḥ ākṣipyate na tu śabdena ucyate
translated: In expressions like the white cow is to be tethered, the individual is transferred by the class for the purpose of accomplishing the tethering enjoined by the Veda, but it is not expressed by the word.

original: viśeṣyaṃ nābhidhā gacchet kṣīṇaśaktirviśeṣaṇe iti nyāyādityupādānalakṣaṇā tu nodāhartavyā /
analyzed: viśeṣyam na abhidhā gacchet kṣīṇa śaktiḥ viśeṣaṇe iti nyāyāt iti upādāna lakṣaṇā tu nā udāhartavyā
translated: Since the rule is that denotation does not go to the qualified, its power being exhausted in the qualifier, figurative usage by transference should not be cited as an example.

original: na hyatra prayojanamasti na vā rūḍhiriyam /
analyzed: na hi atra prayojanam asti na vā rūḍhiḥ iyam
translated: For here there is no purpose, nor is this a conventional meaning.

analyzed: vyakti avinābhāvi tvāt tu jātyāḥ vyaktiḥ ākṣipyate
translated: But the individual is implied by the universal, because it is invariably concomitant with the universal.

analyzed: yathā kriyatām iti atra kartā
translated: Just as in Let it be done, the agent is implied.

analyzed: kuru iti atra karma
translated: In Do it, the object is implied.

analyzed: praviśa piṇḍīm ityādau gṛham bhakṣaya ityādi ca
translated: In Enter the hut, Eat the cake, etc., and so on.

original: pīno devadatto divā na bhuṅkte ityatra ca rātribhojanaṃ na lakṣyate śrutārthāpatterarthāpattervā tasya viṣayatvāt /
analyzed: pīnaḥ devadattaḥ divā na bhuṅkte iti atra ca rātri bhojanam na lakṣyate śruta arthāpatteḥ arthāpatteḥ vā tasya viṣaya tvāt
translated: And in Fat Devadatta does not eat during the day, the eating at night is not inferred, because that is the domain of either verbal implication or implication through the understanding of the meaning of a sentence.

original: gaṅgāyāṃ ghoṣaḥ ityatra taṭasya ghoṣādhikaraṇatvasiddhaye gaṅgāśabdaḥ svārthamarpayati ityevamādau lakṣaṇenaiṣā lakṣaṇā /
analyzed: gaṅgāyām ghoṣaḥ iti atra taṭasya ghoṣa adhikaraṇa tva siddhaye gaṅgā śabdaḥ sva artham arpayati iti evamādau lakṣaṇena eṣā lakṣaṇā
translated: In The village on the bank of the Ganges, the word Ganges conveys its own meaning in order to establish the bank as the locus of the village. In such cases, this is figurative meaning based on indication.

analyzed: ubhaya rūpā ca iyam śuddhā
translated: And this is of two kinds, pure and mixed.

analyzed: upacāreṇa a miśrita tvāt
translated: It is pure because it is not mixed with metaphor.

original: anayorlakṣyasya lakṣakasya ca na bhedarūpaṃ tāṭasthyam /
analyzed: anayoḥ lakṣyasya lakṣakasya ca na bheda rūpam tāṭasthyam
translated: There is no difference between the indicated and the indicator in the form of externality.

original: taṭādīnāṃ gaṅgādiśabdaiḥ pratipādane tattvapratipattau hi pratipipādayiṣitaprayojanasaṃpratyayaḥ /
analyzed: taṭa ādīnām gaṅgā ādi śabdaiḥ pratipādane tattva pratipattau hi pratipipādayiṣita prayojana saṃpratyayaḥ
translated: When the bank, etc. are conveyed by the words Ganges, etc., the understanding of their true nature leads to the understanding of the intended purpose.

original: gaṅgāsaṃbandhamātrapratītau tu gaṅgātaṭe ghoṣa iti mukhyaśabdābhidhānāllakṣaṇāyāḥ ko bhedaḥ ////
analyzed: gaṅgā saṃbandha mātra pratītau tu gaṅgā taṭe ghoṣaḥ iti mukhya śabda abhidhānāt lakṣaṇāyāḥ kaḥ bhedaḥ
translated: But if only the connection with the Ganges is understood, what is the difference between that and the primary meaning of the words the village on the bank of the Ganges, since there is no secondary meaning?

analyzed: sā āropā anyā tu yatra uktau viṣayī viṣayaḥ tathā
translated: But that which is called superimposition is where the object and the subject are stated.

original: āropyamāṇaḥ āropaviṣayaśca yatrānapahnutabhedau sāmānādhikaraṇyena nirdiśyete sā lakṣaṇā sāropā //

translated: That is secondary meaning where the superimposed and the object of superimposition are indicated with co-reference without denying their difference.

translated: When another is superimposed on the subject, it is said to have a conclusion.🔽When another, the object of superimposition, is present, superimposed on the subject, it is said to have a conclusion.

analyzed: bhedau imau ca sādṛśyāt sambandha antarataḥ tathā
translated: These two differences are known to be figurative and literal, based on similarity and other relations.

analyzed: gauṇau śuddhau ca vijñeyau
translated: They should be known as figurative and literal.

original: imāvāropādhyavasānarūpau sādṛśyahetū bhedau gaurvāhīkaḥ ityatra gaurayam ityatra ca /

translated: These two differences, based on similarity, are figurative - the cow is the Brahmin and this is the cow.

original: atra hi svārthasahacāriṇo guṇā jāḍyamāndyādayo lakṣyamāṇā api gośabdasya parārthābhidhāne pravṛttinimittatvamupayāntiṃ iti kecit /

translated: Here some say that even though the qualities such as dullness and slowness that accompany one's own meaning are indicated, they become the cause of usage in the expression of another's meaning by the word cow.

analyzed: lakṣyamāṇa guṇaiḥ yogāt vṛtteḥ iṣṭā tu gauṇa tām iti

analyzed: avinābhāvaḥ saṃbandha mātram na tu nāntarīyaka tvam

translated: And since invariable concomitance is established by implication itself, secondary usage is not useful, as has been said.🔽And in expressions like life-sustaining and this is life itself, there is a relation other than similarity, such as the relation of cause and effect.

analyzed: vibhāva ādi prayoge tasya pratipatteḥ ca iti anvaya vyatirekābhyām vibhāva ādi abhidhāna dvāreṇa eva
translated: if the suggestive element and the like are employed. Thus, by the method of agreement and difference, it is ascertained that it is understood only through the denotation of the suggestive element and the like.

analyzed: pratīyate iti niścīyate 🔽tena asau vyaṅgyaḥ eva
translated: Therefore, it is only suggested.

original: mukhyārthabādhādyabhāvānna punarlakṣaṇīyaḥ /🔽arthāntarasaṃkramitātyantatiraskṛtavācyayorvastumātrarūpaṃ vyaṅgyaṃ vinā lakṣaṇaiva na bhavatīti prāk pratipāditam /
analyzed: mukhya artha bādhā ādi abhāvāt na punar lakṣaṇīyaḥ  artha antara saṃkramita atyanta tiraskṛta vācyayoḥ vastu mātra rūpam vyaṅgyam vinā lakṣaṇā eva na bhavati iti prāk pratipāditam
translated: It is not to be defined again because there is no contradiction of the primary meaning and so on.🔽It has been explained earlier that in cases of transference to another meaning and complete concealment of the denoted meaning, there is no definition without the suggested meaning in the form of mere fact.

original: śabdaśaktimūle tu abhidhāyā niyantraṇenānabhidheyasyārthāntarasya tena sahopamāderaraṃlaṅkārasya ca nirvivādaṃ vyaṅgatvam /
analyzed: śabda śakti mūle tu abhidhāyāḥ niyantraṇena anabhidheyasya artha antarasya tena saha upamā ādeḥ araṃlaṅkārasya ca nirvivādam vyaṅga tvam
translated: But in the case of suggestion based on the power of words, when denotation is restricted, there is no doubt that the suggested meaning is of a figure of speech such as simile, etc., which is not denoted by the word.

analyzed: raṃ is needless
translated: The word 'raṃ' is unnecessary.

original: arthaśaktimūle 'pi viśeṣe saṃketaḥ kartuṃ na yujyate iti sāmānyarūpāṇāṃ padārthānāmākāṅkṣāsaṃnidhiyogyatāvaśātparasparasaṃsargo🔽yatrāpadārtho 'pi viśeṣarūpo vākyārthastatrābhihitānvayavāde
analyzed: artha śakti mūle pi viśeṣe saṃketaḥ kartum na yujyate iti sāmānya rūpāṇām padārthānām ākāṅkṣā saṃnidhi yogya tā vaśāt paraspara saṃsargaḥ  viśeṣa rūpaḥ vākya arthaḥ tatra abhihita anvaya vāde
translated: Even in the case of suggestion based on the power of meaning, it is not proper to make a convention regarding a particular case. Therefore, the general forms of word meanings, by the force of expectancy, proximity and fitness, combine with each other.🔽Where the meaning of a word is also in the form of a particular sentence meaning, what is the situation there in the theory of abhihitanaya

analyzed: kā vārttā vyaṅgyasya abhidheya tāyām
translated: when the suggested meaning is regarded as denoted?

analyzed: yam api āhuḥ  śabda vṛddha abhidheyān ca pratyakṣeṇa atra paśyati
translated: They also say:🔽Here he sees by direct perception the words, the elders, and the denoted meanings,

analyzed: śrotuḥ ca pratipanna tvam anumānena ceṣṭayā
translated: and the understanding of the listener by inference through his gestures.

analyzed: anyathā anupapattyā tu bodhet śaktim dvaya ātmikām
translated: But by the non-apprehension of any other cause, he understands the twofold power of the word to convey the meaning.

analyzed: arthāpattyā avabodheta saṃbandham tri pramāṇakam
translated: One would understand the relation established by the three means of knowledge through presumption.

analyzed: kumārilabhaṭṭa  iti pratipādita diśā devadatta gām ānaya ityādi uttama vṛddha vākya prayogāt deśa antaram
translated: Kumārila Bhatta.🔽Thus, in the manner explained, when the elder says Devadatta, bring the cow, and the middle-aged person brings an object with a dewlap etc. to a different place,

original: sāsnādimantamarthaṃ madhyamavṛddhe nayati sati anenāsmādvākyādevaṃvidho 'rthaḥ pratipannaḥ
analyzed: sāsnādimantam artham madhyama vṛddhe nayati sati anena asmāt vākyāt evaṃvidhaḥ rthaḥ pratipannaḥ
translated: it is understood that this object of such and such a kind has been understood from this sentence.

analyzed: iti tad ceṣṭayā anumāya tayoḥ akhaṇḍa vākya vākyārthayoḥ arthāpattyā vācya vācaka bhāva lakṣaṇam
translated: By inferring that from his behavior, through presumption one ascertains the relation characterized by the relation of denoted and denotator between the indivisible sentence and its meaning,

analyzed: saṃbandham avadhārya bālaḥ tatra vyutpadyate
translated: and the child becomes acquainted with that.

original: parataḥ caitra gāmānaya devadatta aśvamānaya devadatta gāṃ naya ityādivākyaprayoge tasya tasya🔽śabdasya taṃ tamarthamavadhārayatīti anvayavyatirekābhyāṃ pravṛttinivṛttikāri vākyameva🔽prayogayogyamiti vākyasthitānāmeva padānāmanvitaiḥ padārthairanvitānāmeva saṃketo
analyzed: paratas caitra gām ānaya devadatta aśvam ānaya devadatta gām naya ityādi vākya prayoge tasya tasya  śabdasya tam tam artham avadhārayati iti anvaya vyatirekābhyām pravṛtti nivṛtti kāri vākyam eva  prayoga yogyam iti vākya sthitānām eva padānām anvitaiḥ padārthaiḥ anvitānām eva saṃketaḥ
translated: And when the other person uses the sentence Caitra, bring the cow, Devadatta, bring the horse, Devadatta, lead the cow, etc., he ascertains the meaning of each🔽word. Thus, by positive and negative concomitance, only that sentence which causes engagement and disengagement🔽is fit for use. Therefore, the convention is grasped only of the related word-meanings,

original: gṛhyate iti viśiṣṭā eva padārthā vākyārthāḥ /
analyzed: gṛhyate iti viśiṣṭāḥ eva padārthāḥ vākya arthāḥ
translated: which are situated in the sentence, as related to the related word-meanings. Thus, only the qualified word-meanings are the meanings of the sentence.

analyzed: na tu padārthānām vaiśiṣṭyam
translated: But not the distinction of the meanings of words.

original: yadyapi vākyāntaraprayujyamānānyapi pratyabhijñāpratyayena tānyevaitāni padāni niścīyanta iti padārthāntaramātreṇānvitaḥ padārthaḥ saṃketagocaraḥ
analyzed: yadi api vākya antara prayujyamānāni api pratyabhijñā pratyayena tāni eva etāni padāni niścīyante iti padārtha antara mātreṇa anvitaḥ padārthaḥ saṃketa gocaraḥ
translated: Even though those very words are ascertained by the recognition cognition even when used in a different sentence, the meaning of a word is connected only with another word, being the sphere of convention.

original: tathāpi sāmānyāvacchādito viśeṣarūpa evāsau🔽pratipadyate vyatiṣaktānāṃ padārthānāṃ tathābhūtatvādityanvitābhidhānavādinaḥ /
analyzed: tathā api sāmānya avacchāditaḥ viśeṣa rūpaḥ eva asau  pratipadyate vyatiṣaktānām padārthānām tathābhūta tvāt iti anvita abhidhāna vādinaḥ
translated: However, it is understood in the form of a particular concealed by the universal.🔽Because the meanings of the combined words are of that nature, according to those who advocate the theory of the expression of the related meaning.

original: teṣāmapi mate sāmānyaviśeṣarūpaḥ padārhaḥ saṃketaviṣaya ityativiśeṣabhūto vākyārthāntargatosaṃketitatvādavācya
analyzed: teṣām api mate sāmānya viśeṣa rūpaḥ padārhaḥ saṃketa viṣayaḥ iti ati viśeṣa bhūtaḥ vākya artha antargata usaṃketita tvāt avācya
translated: Even according to their view, the meaning of a word in the form of a universal and a particular is the object of convention. Therefore, the expressed meaning, which is extremely specific and included within the meaning of a sentence, is not denotable

original: eva yatra padārthaḥ pratipadyate tatra dūre arthāntarabhūtasya niḥśeṣacyutetyādau vidhyādeścarcā /
analyzed: eva yatra padārthaḥ pratipadyate tatra dūre artha antara bhūtasya niḥśeṣa cyuta ityādau vidhi ādeḥ carcā
translated: because it is the object of convention. Where the meaning of a word is understood, there is a long way to go for the discussion of the expressed meaning in the form of a different meaning, such as in niḥśeṣacyute etc.

original: ananvito 'rtho 'bhihitānvaye padārthāntaramātreṇānvitastvanvitābhidhāne anvitaviśeṣastvavācya eva ityubhayanaye 'pyapadārtha eva vākyārthaḥ
analyzed: ananvitaḥ rthaḥ bhihita anvaye padārtha antara mātreṇa anvitaḥ tu anvita abhidhāne anvita viśeṣaḥ tu avācyaḥ eva iti ubhaya naye pi apadārthaḥ eva vākya arthaḥ
translated: The meaning that is not related is the meaning that is related only with another word in the case of the theory of the relation of denotation and meaning, but the particular of the related meaning is indeed inexpressible. Thus, even in both theories, the meaning of a sentence is indeed not the meaning of a word.

analyzed: yat api ucyate naimittika anusāreṇa nimittāni kalpyante iti
translated: And what is said, that the causes are imagined according to the enjoined acts,

original: tatra nimittatvaṃ kārakatvaṃ jñāpakatvaṃ vā śabdasya /
analyzed: tatra nimitta tvam kāraka tvam jñāpaka tvam vā śabdasya
translated: there the causal character of the word is either the character of an agent or the character of an indicator.

analyzed: prakāśaka tvāt na kāraka tvam
translated: It is not the character of an agent because it is a revealer.

analyzed: jñāpaka tvam tu ajñātasya katham
translated: But how can there be the character of an indicator of what is unknown?

original: jñātatvañca saṃketenaiva sa cānvitamātre evaṃ ca nimittasya niyatanimittatvaṃ🔽yāvanna niścitaṃ tāvannaimittikasya pratītireva katham iti 'naimittikānusāreṇa nimittāni kalpyante ' /
analyzed: jñāta tvam ca saṃketena eva sa ca anvita mātre evam ca nimittasya niyata nimitta tvam  yāvat na niścitam tāvat naimittikasya pratītiḥ eva katham iti naimittika anusāreṇa nimittāni kalpyante
translated: And the known character is only by convention, and that is only in what is related. Thus the cause has a definite cause.

analyzed: iti avicārita abhidhānam
translated: As long as it is not ascertained, how can there be the cognition of the enjoined act? Thus, 'the causes are imagined according to the enjoined acts' is an expression without reflection.

original: ye tvabhidadhati so 'yamiṣoriva dīrghadīrghataro vyāpāraḥ iti yatparaḥ śabdaḥ sa śabdārthaḥ iti vidhirevātra vācya iti /
analyzed: ye tu abhidadhati saḥ yam iṣoḥ iva dīrgha dīrghataraḥ vyāpāraḥ iti yad paraḥ śabdaḥ sa śabda arthaḥ iti vidhiḥ eva atra vācyaḥ iti
translated: But those who declare that this is a much longer operation like the long arrow, that the meaning of the word is what the word is about, that only the injunction is to be expressed here,

analyzed: te pi a tātparya jñāḥ tātparya vācoyukteḥ devānām priyāḥ
translated: they, not knowing the purport, are dear to the gods by the statement of purport.

original: tathāhi bhūtavyasamuccāraṇe bhūtaṃ bhavyāyopadiśyate iti kārakapadārthāḥ kriyābhisaṇbandhāt sādhyāmānatāṃ prāpnuvanti /
analyzed: tathā hi bhūtavya samuccāraṇe bhūtam bhavyāya upadiśyate iti kāraka padārthāḥ kriyā abhisaṇbandhāt sādhya amāna tām prāpnuvanti
translated: For thus, when the past and future are uttered together, the past is taught for the future. Thus the meanings of the words denoting agents, by the connection with the verb, attain the state of being to be accomplished.

analyzed: tatas ca adagdha dahana nyāyena yāvat aprāptam tāvat vidhīyate
translated: And then, by the principle of the unburnt fire-stick, it is enjoined only up to what is not already established.

analyzed: yathā ṛtvij pracaraṇe pramāṇa antarāt siddhe
translated: For example, in the case of the priests performing the ritual, which is established by other means,

original: lohitoṣṇīṣā ṛtvijaḥ pracaranti ityatra lohitoṣṇīṣatvamātraṃ vidheyaṃ havanasyānyataḥ siddheḥ dadhnā juhoti ityādau dadhyādeḥ karaṇatvamātraṃ
analyzed: lohita uṣṇīṣāḥ ṛtvijaḥ pracaranti iti atra lohita uṣṇīṣa tva mātram vidheyam havanasya anyatas siddheḥ dadhnā juhoti ityādau dadhi ādeḥ karaṇa tva mātram
translated: in the sentence The priests perform the ritual with red turbans, only the redness of the turbans is to be enjoined, because the offering is established by other means. In the case of sentences like One should offer oblations with curd, the instrumentality of curd etc.

analyzed: vidheyam
translated: is to be enjoined.

original: kvacidubhayavidhiḥ kvacittrividhirapi yathā raktaṃ paṭaṃ vayaḥ ityādau ekavidhirdvividhistrividhirvā /
analyzed: kvacid ubhaya vidhiḥ kvacid tri vidhiḥ api yathā raktam paṭam vayaḥ ityādau eka vidhiḥ dvi vidhiḥ tri vidhiḥ vā
translated: In some cases, there is injunction of both, and in some cases, even of three, as in the case of One should wear a red cloth etc., where there is either one injunction, or two injunctions, or three injunctions.

original: tataśca yadeva vidheyaṃ tatraiva tātparyam ityupāttasyava śabdasyārthe tātparya na tu pratītamātre evaṃ hi pūrvo dhāvati ityādāvaparādyathapi
analyzed: tatas ca yat eva vidheyam tatra eva tātparyam iti śabdasya arthe na tu pratīta mātre evam hi pūrvaḥ dhāvati ityādau
translated: And then, where there is something to be enjoined, there is the purport. Thus, the purport is in the meaning of the word that is used, not merely in what is understood. Otherwise, in sentences like The former runs, the purport would be in the latter part also.

analyzed: kvacid tātparyam syāt
translated: In some cases, there may be purport.

original: yattu viṣaṃ bhakṣaya mā cānya gṛhe bhuṅkthāḥ ityatra etadgṛhe na bhoktavyam ityatra tātparyamiti sa eva vākyārtha iti /
analyzed: yat tu viṣam bhakṣaya mā ca anya gṛhe bhuṅkthāḥ iti atra etad gṛhe na bhoktavyam iti atra tātparyam iti saḥ eva vākya arthaḥ iti
translated: But in the case of the sentence Eat poison, do not eat in another's house, if the purport is that One should not eat in this house, then that alone is the meaning of the sentence.

original: ucyate tatra cakāra ekavākyatāsūcanārthaḥ na cākhyātavākyayor dvayoraṅgāṅgibhāva
analyzed: ucyate tatra cakāraḥ ekavākyatā sūcana arthaḥ na ca ākhyāta vākyayoḥ dvayoḥ aṅga aṅgibhāva
translated: It is said that the word 'ca' (and) there indicates syntactical unity. And the two sentences with verbs cannot have the relation of primary and secondary.

original: iti viṣabhakṣaṇavākyasya suhṛdvākyatvenāṅgatā kalpanīyeti viṣabhakṣaṇādapi duṣṭametadgṛhe
analyzed: iti viṣa bhakṣaṇa vākyasya suhṛd vākya tvena aṅga tā kalpanīyā iti viṣa bhakṣaṇāt api duṣṭam etat gṛhe
translated: So the sentence about eating poison must be regarded as a secondary statement, like the friend's words. Thus, the food in his house is worse than even eating poison.

original: bhojanamiti sarvathā māsya gṛhe bhuṅkthāḥ iti /
analyzed: bhojanam iti sarvathā mā asya gṛhe bhuṅkthāḥ iti
translated: So by all means do not eat in his house.

original: upāttaśabdārthe eva tātparyam /🔽yadi śabdaśruterantaraṃ yāvānartho labhyate tāvati śabdasyābhidhaiva vyāpāraḥ tataḥ kathaṃ 'brāhmaṇa putraste jātaḥ brāhmaṇa kanyā te garbhiṇī' /
analyzed: upātta śabda arthe eva tātparyam  yadi śabda śruteḥ antaram yāvān arthaḥ labhyate tāvati śabdasya abhidhā eva vyāpāraḥ tatas katham brāhmaṇa putraḥ te jātaḥ brāhmaṇa kanyā te garbhiṇī
translated: The purport is only in the meaning of the words used.

analyzed: ityādau harṣa śoka ādīnām api na vācya tvam
translated: If the operation of a word is only to denote the meaning that is understood as soon as the word is heard, then how can joy, sorrow, etc. not be denoted in statements like 'A son is born to you, O Brahmin' and 'O Brahmin, a daughter is pregnant to you'?

analyzed: kasmāt ca lakṣaṇā lakṣaṇīye pi arthe dīrgha dīrghatara abhidhā vyaāpāreṇa eva pratīti siddheḥ
translated: And why should there be secondary meaning when the meaning to be indicated is understood by the operation of denotation itself, which is longer and longer?

original: kimiti ca śrutiliṅgavākyaprakaraṇasthānasamākhyānāṃ pūrvapūrvabalīyastvam ityanvitābhidhānavāde 'pi vidherapi siddhaṃ vyaṅgyatvam //
analyzed: kim iti ca śruti liṅga vākya prakaraṇa sthāna samākhyānām pūrva pūrva balīyaḥ tvam iti anvita abhidhāna vāde vidheḥ api siddham vyaṅgya tvam
translated: And why should there be the increasing strength of direct statement, indication, sentence, context, position, and order in the theory of expressed meaning through syntactical relation? Even in that theory, it is established that even the injunction is to be conveyed.

original: kiṃ ca kuru rucim iti padayorvaiparītye kāvyāntarvartini kathaṃ duṣṭatvam /
analyzed: kim ca kuru rucim iti padayoḥ vaiparītye kāvya antar vartini katham duṣṭa tvam
translated: Moreover, in the case of the expression 'kuru ruci', where there is a reversal of the words, how can it be defective within poetry?

original: na hmatrāsabhyo 'rthaḥ padārthāntarairanvitaḥ ityanabhidheya eveti evamādi aparityājyaṃ syāt /🔽yadi ca vācyavācakatvavyatirekeṇa vyaṅgyavyañjakabhāvo nābhyupeyate tadāsādhutvādīnāṃ nityadoṣatvaṃ kaṣṭatvādīnāmanityadoṣatvamiti
analyzed: na rthaḥ padārtha antaraiḥ anvitaḥ iti anabhidheyaḥ eva iti evamādi aparityājyam syāt  yadi ca vācya vācaka tva vyatirekeṇa vyaṅgya vyañjaka bhāvaḥ na abhyupeyate tadā asādhu tva ādīnām nitya doṣa tvam kaṣṭa tva ādīnām anitya doṣa tvam iti
translated: For then the meaning would not be connected with other word meanings, and would thus be inexpressible. Such things would have to be accepted.🔽And if the relation of the suggested and the suggestive is not accepted apart from the relation of the denoted and the denotative, then the classification of incorrectness etc. as permanent faults and difficulty etc. as non-permanent faults

analyzed: vibhāga karaṇam anupapannam syāt
translated: would be illogical.

analyzed: na ca anupapannam sarvasya eva vibhakta tayā pratibhāsāt
translated: And it is not illogical, because it is perceived as divided by everyone.

original: vācyavācakabhāvavyatirekeṇa vyaṅgyavyañjakatāśrayaṇe tu vyaṅgyasya bahuvidhatvāt kvacideva kasyacidevaucityenopapadyata eva vibhāgavyavasthā
analyzed: vācya vācaka bhāva vyatirekeṇa vyaṅgya vyañjaka tā āśrayaṇe tu vyaṅgyasya bahuvidha tvāt kvacid eva kasyacid eva aucityena upapadyate eva vibhāga vyavasthā
translated: But when the relation of the suggested and the suggestive is accepted apart from the relation of the denoted and the denotative, then due to the suggestiveness being of many kinds, it is logically possible to establish the division by the appropriateness of some in some cases only.

original: dvayaṃ gataṃ saṃprati śocanīyatāṃ samāgamaprārthanayā kapālinaḥ /
analyzed: dvayam gatam saṃprati śocanīya tām samāgama prārthanayā kapālinaḥ
translated: The two have now become objects of pity by the request for union of the skull-bearer.

analyzed: ityādau pināki ādi pada vailakṣaṇyena kim iti kapāli ādi padānām kāvya anuguṇa tvam
translated: In such expressions, why should the words 'kapalī' etc. be favorable to poetry by being different from the words 'pinākī' etc.?

original: api ca vācyo 'rthaḥ sarvān pratipattṝn prati ekarūpa eveti niyato 'sau /
analyzed: api ca vācyaḥ rthaḥ sarvān pratipattṝn prati eka rūpaḥ eva iti niyataḥ sau
translated: Moreover, the expressed meaning is fixed, being the same for all comprehenders.

original: na hi gatostamarkaḥ ityādau vācyo 'rthaḥ kvacidanyathā bhavati /
analyzed: na hi gatoḥ tam arkaḥ ityādau vācyaḥ rthaḥ kvacid anyathā bhavati
translated: For in The sun has set and so on, the expressed meaning is never otherwise for anyone.

analyzed: pratīyamānaḥ tu tad tad prakaraṇa vaktṛ pratipattṛ ādi viśeṣa sahāya tayā nānātvam
translated: But the suggested meaning, by the help of the particular context, speaker, listener, etc., assumes various forms.

original: bhajate / tathā ca gato 'stamarkaḥ ityataḥ sapatnaṃ pratyavaskandanāvasara iti🔽abhisaraṇamupakramyatāmiti prāptaprāyaste preyāniti karmakaraṇānnivartāmaha iti sāṃdhyo🔽vidhirupakramyatāmiti dūraṃ mā gā iti surabhayo gṛhaṃ praveśyantāmiti saṃtāpodhunā
analyzed: bhajate tathā ca gataḥ stam arkaḥ iti atas sapatnam pratyavaskandana avasaraḥ iti  abhisaraṇam upakramyatām iti prāpta prāyaḥ te preyān iti karma karaṇāt nivartāmahe iti sāṃdhyaḥ  vidhiḥ upakramyatām iti dūram mā gāḥ iti surabhayaḥ gṛham praveśyantām iti saṃtāpa udhunā
translated: And thus, from The sun has set, it suggests This is the time to attack the enemy,🔽Let us set out on our journey, Your beloved is almost within reach, Let us return from our work, Let us begin the evening rites,

original: na bhavatīti vikreyavastūni saṃhriyantāmiti nāgatodyāpi preyānityādiranavadhirvyaṅgyo🔽'rthaḥ tatra tatra pratibhāti /
analyzed: na bhavati iti vikreya vastūni saṃhriyantām iti na āgata udyā api preyān ityādiḥ anavadhiḥ vyaṅgyaḥ  rthaḥ tatra tatra pratibhāti
translated: Do not go far, Let the fragrant flowers be brought in, You are not well now, Let the things to be sold be collected, Your beloved has not yet come - such an infinite variety of suggested meanings appears here and there.
